entry.title: Combined summary - Max Block Size: Simple Voting Procedure
entry.summary: The context revolves around proposals for changing the voting system for miners in Bitcoin. One such proposal suggests adding an output at tx.vout[0] with OP_RETURN data to the coinbase transaction to vote for or against increasing the block size limit. The proposal aims to create a non-gameable voting system and avoid artificially bloated blocks. However, there are concerns that miners might want larger blocks than the rest of the network could bear, leading to centralization of Bitcoin in the hands of a few large mining pools.Another proposal suggests changing the voting system within Bitcoin to give small miners a fair chance. The proposed changes suggest that votes need to be 100%, not 50.01%, and users who make transactions should also have a vote. Fee incentives should attract legitimate votes from miners while cheating miners will be defeated by another miner who includes those votes and takes the fees. However, some members of the community are still hesitant about giving miners so much power.There is also an email exchange between Stephen Morse and Pindar Wong discussing the idea of separating hard/soft fork upgrades and establishing a process for the community to self-determine the way forward in a transparent and verifiable manner. Wong believes that mining pools in China currently have too much power, which could be unhealthy for the network. However, some members of the community feel uncomfortable about giving miners too much power. Instead, they suggest finding a level of rough consensus where members of the community feel comfortable enough to do this upgrade in their respective codebase.Overall, these proposals face challenges and may not receive enough support to be merged into Bitcoin Core. Some members of the community are hesitant about giving miners too much power, as they are not the only ones affected by the choice of block size limit. Ultimately, finding a solution that balances the interests of all stakeholders may be difficult but necessary for the continued growth and success of Bitcoin.
